titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the John A. Pino papers FA1301
titlestmt.author: Katie Martin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-10-04 04:16:17 -0400.

did.unittitle: John A. Pino papers

physdesc.extent: 5 letter document containers, 6 legal document container, 1 half-legal document container, 1 half-letter document container, 1 Paige box of photographs, and an oversize materials box

did.langmaterial: English; Many materials related to work in Latin America are in Spanish

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John A. Pino earned a BS in Agriculture in 1947 and PhD in Zoology in 1951 from Rutgers University. He was an associate professor and conducted research in the Department of Poultry Science at Rutgers until 1955 when he accepted an animal scientist position with the Rockefeller Foundation's Mexican Agricultural Program. In 1960, Pino became director of the program and later transferred to the Foundation's headquarters in New York to become director of the Agricultural Science Program in 1970. He retired from the Rockefeller Foundation in 1983 to serve as Agricultural Science Advisor to the Inter-American Development Bank until 1986. Dr. Pino served as a member of the National Research Council's Board on Agriculture from 1973-1977 and again beginning in 1983. He became a senior fellow of the National Research Council in 1986. Pino also served as Executive Director of CILCA, the International Liaison Committee for Food Corps Programs, which provided low-cost assistance to rural populations in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. Beginning in 1990, Pino served as a consultant to agricultural research organizations. A leader in the Green Revolution, Pino helped lead efforts to establish the world network of International Agricultural Research Centers to improve basic food production.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to the RAC by John A. Pino in 2012 and ingested by RAC as Accession 2012:067.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Special format items have been separated from the body of the collection and assigned a unique separation number, as noted. Requests to access open special formats should reference the unique separation number.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The John A. Pino papers are arranged into five series reflecting Pino's original arrangement and the years he held leadership positions in agricultural organizations:

1. International Liaison Committee for Food Corps Programs (CILCA) 1981-2000 2. Inter-American Institute for Cooperation on Agriculture (IICA), 1986-1997 3. National Bureau of Animal Genetic Resources (NGABR), 1987-1996 4. Rockefeller Foundation and Rutgers Poultry Projects, 1950-1983 5. National Research Council, Board on Agriculture, and Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), 1984-2001

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The John A. Pino papers contain correspondence, reports, photographs, clippings, publications, meeting minutes, bulletins, and notes related to Pino's more than 50-year career in international agricultural research and development.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clippings and photographs, Note describing scrapbook: page 1: unknown, Agosto Aguilera, Martin Gonzalez, Pedro Solana, John Ping; page 2: Pedro Solana, Eduardo Rivera, Emil Arias, unknown, Agosto Aguilera, FAO seated at table head, Dan Hagen, Oscar Valdez Ornelas, John Pino, Edsel Bixter, Henk Tunissien; page 3: upper left John Pino, Martin Gonzalez, Gilbert Valdez, Ned Raun, Henk Tunissien, Oscar Valdez Ornelas, center Ned Raun, Gilberto Valdez, lower left Ned Raun Gilberto Valdez, and Martin Gonzalez; page 3: upper right Dan Hagen lower right Ned Raun Gilberto Valdez, John Pino, Oscar Ornelas, Dan Hagen, Hank Tuniessin, Group photo with Livestock Association - Chihuahua, Group photo - meeting at Veterinary School - Mexico 3rd left Oscar Ornelas, Ernesto Bachtold, Pablo Zikrold, John Pino; Meeting with Subsecretary of livestock Mexico City center Oscar Ornelas right Acevedos, National Inst. Livestock Research - Palo Alto, Mexico center President Adolfo Lopez Mateas right of president - Inginero Julian Rodriguez Adams, John Pino; President of Mexico and Livestock Association; top left l-r - Agosto Aguilera, Alexander Cuadra, John Pino, bottom John Pino giving talk; Picture of John Pino and Ned Raun and newspaper clippings, pictures from experiment station at Chihuahua; group from veterinary school, Ralph Richardson and Doug Barnes (RF staff), John Pino in hat - Chihuahua; Veterinary School staff in Peru, Top left: Dr. Guierlmo Schnazi (veterinarian), Don Davis, and John Pino; ITESM - Dr. Michel, John Pino, director of agronomy school in Monterey; Top left Agronomy School in Monterey, John Pino, director of agronomy school; bottom left: John Pino, Ken Turk; Upper right Ken Turn and staff member from Agronomy School

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access copy currently unavailable. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.
